case_vignette: A 15-month-old boy presents with a history of skin blistering since birth, primarily on his hands, feet, and the perioral face. Blisters and erosions also involve the trunk, some in an annular configuration. There is no family history of neonatal blistering or skin fragility. Over time, the patient has had a decreased number of new vesicles and bullae associated with trauma and friction but has developed thicker skin on the soles of the feet and dystrophic nails.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been getting blisters on my hands, feet, and around my mouth since I was born, and I've also got some on my body that are in a ring shape.
How often do these blisters appear?
They've been happening since birth, but over time there's been fewer new ones when I get bumped or rubbed.
Do any of your family members have a history of similar skin conditions?
No, I don't have any family history of these skin problems.
Do you have any other symptoms like itching or pain along with the blisters?
The case vignette does not mention itching or pain, so I cannot provide that information.
Understood. Have you been diagnosed with any other medical conditions or are you taking any medications?
The case vignette does not provide information about any other medical conditions or medications, so I cannot provide that information.
**Final Diagnosis:** Congenital Erythropoietic Porphyria
